content: The "Children Health Insurance Act of 1996" requires health insurance availability for children through amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes provisions for excise tax on failure to meet coverage requirements and definitions related to access to coverage. The "Children Health Insurance Act of 1996" imposes a tax on group health plans and insurers that fail to meet coverage requirements. The tax amount is 25 percent of premiums received for the plan year. The tax imposed on group health plans and insurers for failing to meet coverage requirements is 25 percent of premiums received for the plan year. For self-insured plans, the cost of coverage is treated as the premium received. The tax imposed on insurers for coverage failures is 25 percent of premiums paid for the plan year. No tax applies if the failure was not discovered despite reasonable diligence or if the failure is corrected within 30 days. The tax imposed on insurers for coverage failures is 25 percent of premiums paid for the plan year. No tax applies if the failure was not discovered despite reasonable diligence or if the failure is corrected within 30 days. If the failure is due to reasonable cause and not willful neglect, the tax may be waived by the Secretary. The tax imposed on insurers for coverage failures is 25 percent of premiums paid for the plan year. The Secretary may waive part or all of the tax if the failure is due to reasonable cause and not willful neglect. The tax does not apply to governmental plans or church plans. Those responsible for the tax are specified in subsection (e). The tax imposed on insurers for coverage failures is 25 percent of premiums paid for the plan year. The tax does not apply to governmental plans or church plans. Those responsible for the tax are specified in subsection (e). "SEC. 9902. REQUIREMENT OF ACCESS TO COVERAGE." Group health plans must offer qualifying coverage for qualifying young dependents of participants or beneficiaries. The offer must be made when a person first becomes a qualifying young dependent and at least annually thereafter. Insurers in the individual market must offer qualifying coverage for individuals under 21 years of age who are US citizens or nationals. Group health plans and insurers in the individual market must provide qualifying coverage for individuals under 21 years of age who are US citizens or nationals. Qualifying coverage includes Medicare benefits without limitations based on pre-existing conditions or waiting periods. Medicare benefits under parts A and B of title XVIII of the Social Security Act, or equivalent benefits, with a maximum coinsurance of $10 or 10% of the payment amount. Well child care benefits cover specific items and services without deductibles or coinsurance. Well child care benefits include newborn and well-baby care, routine office visits, immunizations, laboratory tests, and preventive dental care without deductibles or coinsurance. Well-child care benefits include routine office visits, immunizations, laboratory tests, and preventive dental care. The Secretary, in consultation with the American Academy of Pediatrics, will establish a periodicity schedule for these services. Managed care is permitted without limitations on providers. The term 'qualifying young dependent' refers to an individual under 21 years of age, residing in the US, who is a citizen, national, or alien permanently residing in the US under color of law, and is a dependent as defined in section 152. Managed care is allowed without restrictions on providers for well-child care benefits, including routine office visits, immunizations, laboratory tests, and preventive dental care. "SEC. 9903. DEFINITIONS." "In this chapter, the term 'group health plan' is defined as per section 5000(b)(1), excluding plans with medical benefits limited to coverage in paragraph (2)(B). 'Health insurance coverage' refers to medical care benefits under various policies or contracts, excluding certain exceptions." The term 'group health plan' is defined in this chapter, excluding plans with limited medical benefits. Health insurance coverage includes medical care benefits under policies or contracts, with exceptions for specific types of coverage. The curr_chunk discusses various types of insurance coverage, including Medicare supplemental health insurance, liability insurance, workers' compensation, and more. These coverages can be provided under group health plans or as supplements to other types of insurance. The curr_chunk lists different types of insurance coverage, such as liability insurance, workers' compensation, automobile medical-payment insurance, specified disease coverage, hospital indemnity insurance, short-term limited duration insurance, and other comparable coverages. The curr_chunk defines a health maintenance organization as a federally qualified organization, one recognized under State law, or a similar organization regulated under State law. The curr_chunk defines an insurer as an insurance company, service, or organization licensed to engage in insurance business in a State. The curr_chunk defines an insurer as an insurance company, service, or organization licensed to engage in insurance business in a State, subject to State law regulating insurance. The term 'individual market' refers to health insurance coverage offered to individuals, excluding coverage issued only by an insurer based on association affiliation. The curr_chunk adds definitions for 'beneficiary' and 'participant' from the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. It also includes a clerical amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Subtitle L. Health Insurance Availability for Children. The requirement of section 9902 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 shall take effect on January 1, 1998, applying to coverage offered on or after that date. A refundable tax credit for the purchase of health coverage for children is introduced in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax credit allows individuals to claim 80% of qualified health premiums paid in the taxable year. The credit is applied against tax liability at a rate of $0.50 for each $1 of tax liability. Tax liability is defined as the excess of the tax imposed for the year, reduced by other credits. The term 'tax liability' is the excess of the tax imposed for the year and the taxpayer's social security taxes, minus the credit allowed under section 32. Social security taxes refer to the taxes imposed on amounts received under sections 3101 and 3201(a). The term 'social security taxes' refers to taxes imposed on amounts received by the taxpayer, including taxes on self-employment income and amounts received during the taxable year. The term 'social security taxes' excludes taxes eligible for a special refund under section 6413(c) and any payments made under agreements with American employers under section 3121(l). The term 'qualified health premium' refers to payments for health coverage of a qualifying young dependent, while 'health coverage' is defined as health insurance as per section 9902(b). The term 'qualified health premium' refers to payments for health coverage of a qualifying young dependent, and 'health coverage' is defined as health insurance that includes qualifying coverage. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1997.
